title: Imperial among five universities to share in £2.5 million pot to boost maths
excerpt: Imperial has secure a £500,000 grant from the Maths Degrees for the Future programme.

title: Imperial launches Schools of Convergence Science to drive scientific discovery
excerpt: The new Schools of Convergence Science will help Imperial supercharge scientific discovery and drive economic growth.

title: Food structure plays key role in which gut hormones are released
excerpt: A new study from Imperial has shown that the physical structure of food influences the hormones released as part of digestion.

title: Supportive housing offers cost-effective response to homelessness and opioid use
excerpt: A new study shows that providing housing without requiring prior drug treatment produces major public health gains and cost savings.

title: Update on the 2025-26 budget
excerpt: Stanford’s president and provost provide an update on the university’s budget planning for the 2025-26 academic year.

title: Jeannette Wang named Newman Civic Fellow for strengthening democratic participation
excerpt: The Stanford junior was recognized for her efforts to unite students across political divides and advance civic engagement.

title: Report of the president: Academic Council professoriate appointments
excerpt: The following Academic Council professoriate appointments, promotions, and reappointments were reviewed by the Advisory Board of the Academic Council and approved by the president.

title: How bioengineering Professor Russ Altman uses AI
excerpt: In the first Q&A of a new series, Altman explains why he permits AI in classes, rejects it for recommendation letters, and feels both cautious and optimistic about its future.

title: One surprising fact about plant cells
excerpt: Plants grow from something unexpected – carbon drawn in through tiny pores called stomata. At Stanford, researchers are studying how these structures form to understand plant growth.

title: New study shows how biomass changed over 500 million years
excerpt: While scientists have long known that biodiversity increased over geological time, this is the first study to calculate long-term trends in the total abundance of life. The findings strengthen evidence that conserving biodiversity is critical to the health of people and the planet.

title: One surprising fact about wearable robotics
excerpt: Functional prosthetics date back further than you might think. Today, Stanford researchers are building on this legacy with wearable robotics that rapidly adapt to each user.

title: Stanford Institute for Theoretical Physics named for Leinweber Foundation gift
excerpt: A gift from the Leinweber Foundation names the Leinweber Institute for Theoretical Physics at Stanford, fueling a national effort to explore the universe’s most profound questions.

title: One surprising fact about smart glasses
excerpt: Long before computers existed, a sci-fi story imagined virtual reality. Now, nearly a century later, Stanford engineers are making that once-unthinkable vision real with virtual technologies for spectacles.

title: Seminar explores historical roots of American conservatism
excerpt: In a Stanford Civics Initiative course, students confront the complex tensions that emerge in balancing core constitutional principles and political change.

title: Stanford launches ‘Last Mile’ program to improve mail efficiency and advance sustainability goals
excerpt: The student package processing and delivery system will start this fall and is part of the new Mail and Package Services program announced earlier this year.

title: The ongoing impact of California’s Eaton Fire on mothers
excerpt: Associate Professor Antero Garcia interviewed moms in Pasadena and Altadena to examine the disaster’s toll – uncovering effects ranging from decision fatigue to survivor’s guilt.

title: Sports medicine expert discusses Faith Kipyegon’s record-breaking sub-four-minute mile attempt
excerpt: Emily Kraus answers four questions about the limits of human running, breaking records, and the significance of Kipyegon’s endeavor.

title: Scientists react to first images released by world’s largest digital camera
excerpt: More than 20 years ago, Stanford and SLAC launched the Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, setting in motion a chain of events that helped bring the Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST) to life. On Monday, scientists and engineers reacted to the first images from the NSF–DOE Vera C. Rubin Observatory, marking a historic milestone for LSST and its survey of the southern sky.

title: The bold bet that built a telescope
excerpt: Two decades ago, Stanford and SLAC took a gamble on an unproven telescope design that had no funding, no home, and no official backing. Now, with first images in hand and full operations on the horizon, that bet is on the verge of paying off.

title: John H. Flavell, influential scholar of developmental psychology, has died
excerpt: Remembered for his humility and generosity, Flavell was a giant in his field.

title: What the science says about sunscreen
excerpt: We asked Stanford Medicine dermatologists to clarify the facts about sunscreen products.

title: Board of Trustees holds final meeting of 2024-25 academic year
excerpt: Trustees approved the 2025-26 provisional budget and heard an update on federal policy issues during their June meeting. The Board also engaged with faculty and students on civil discourse and learned more about Stanford’s work in AI and data science.

title: New large language model helps patients understand their radiology reports
excerpt: “RadGPT” cuts through medical jargon to answer common patient questions.

title: Gut microbes could protect us from toxic ‘forever chemicals’
excerpt:
PFAS have been linked with a range of health issues including decreased fertility, developmental delays in children, and a higher risk of certain cancers and cardiovascular diseases.

Scientists at the University of Cambridge have

title: Celebrating sporting success at the 2025 Cambridge University Sports Awards
excerpt: Organised by the University Sports service, the annual ceremony brought together students, staff, alumni, and guests to recognise the exceptional contributions and successes of sports clubs, teams, and individuals across the Univ

title: UK Ambassador to the US visits Cambridge to discuss opportunities for deepening UK-US tech collaboration
excerpt:
As the world’s most intensive science and technology cluster, Cambridge is driving breakthrough research and attracting global investment across quantum, life sciences, and biotech.

During his visit, hosted by Founders

title: Patient with debilitating inherited condition receives new approved treatment  on the NHS in Europe first
excerpt:
Mary Catchpole, 19, was given a newly licensed drug called leniolisib (or Joenja) at Addenbrooke’s Hospital in Cambridge. It is the first ever targeted treatment for a rare, inherited immunodeficiency called Activated PI3-Kinase delta syndrome (APDS).

People with APDS have a weakened immune syst

title: Co-founder of billion-dollar AI for autonomous driving company and Cambridge alumnus wins Princess Royal Silver Medal
excerpt:
Wayve is one of the UK’s most valuable deep-tech startups, backed by more than $1 billion (about £730 million) in funding. Alex Kendall co-founded the company in 2017 following his PhD at the University of Cambridge, where he pioneered a contrarian approach to self-driving cars.

At a time when the industry relied heavily on rule-based systems, maps and multiple

title: Celebrating Lord Sainsbury of Turville’s ‘selfless’ service as Chancellor
excerpt:
At a reception at the Vice-Chancellor’s Lodge this week, which celebrated his service to the University, Lord Sainsbury talked fondly about his own time as a student at Cambridge, and said: “It has been a great honour and pleasure to be Chancellor of the University of Cambridge, one of the world’s greatest universities.

“Over the years, I have watched with awe how the

title: AI art protection tools still leave creators at risk, researchers say
excerpt:
So say a team of researchers who have uncovered significant weaknesses in two of the art protection tools most used by artists to safeguard their work.

According to their creators, Glaze and NightShade were both developed to protect human creatives against the invasive uses of generative artificial

title: Autonomous bus trial will carry passengers between Eddington and Cambridge West
excerpt:
A 15-seater autonomous bus will operate between Madingley Road Park & Ride, and around the University's Eddington neighbourhood and Cambridge West Innovation District. 

The early phase of the trial, following extensive vir

title: Rubin Observatory reveals first images
excerpt: The Rubin Observatory, jointly funded by the US National Science Foundation and the US Department of Energy’s Office of Science, has released its first imagery, showing cosmic phenomena at an unprecedented scale.

title: World first trial compares two opposite IBS  treatments
excerpt: An international research team led by the University of Melbourne will run a world-first head-to-head clinical trial, comparing the effectiveness of two opposite Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) treatments, the low FODMAP* diet and exposure-based cognitive behavioural therapy.

title: Australia India Indonesia strategic dialogue held in Canberra
excerpt: Experts from Australia, India and Indonesia met in Canberra today for a high-level maritime security dialogue to discuss how the three countries can create closer defence and security ties to promote peace, stability and prosperity across the Indo-Pacific.

title: Parkinson’s drug effective in treating persistent depression
excerpt: A drug used for Parkinson’s disease has been shown to be effective in reducing the symptoms of difficult to treat depression, in a study led by the University of Oxford.

title: Construction begins on state-of-the-art research facility
excerpt: The University of Oxford held a groundbreaking ceremony on Tuesday 24 June to celebrate the start of construction of the Cyrus Poonawalla Vaccines Research Building. The ceremony marks a significant milestone in Oxford’s mission to counter and constrain global health threats.

title: Oxford to lead new £50m MRC Centre to develop brain stimulation device-based therapies
excerpt: A new Medical Research Council Centre of Research Excellence (MRC CoRE) aims to develop brain stimulation devices to treat conditions such as Parkinson’s, dementia, stroke and childhood epilepsy.

title: Professor Karen Leeder awarded 2025 Griffin Poetry Prize
excerpt: Professor Karen Leeder, Schwarz-Taylor Chair of German Language and Literature, Faculty of Medieval and Modern Languages, has won the 2025 Griffin Poetry Prize for her English translation of Psyche Running: Selected Poems 2005–2022 by renowned German poet Durs Grünbein.

title: ‘Single shot’ malaria vaccine delivery system could transform global immunisation
excerpt: Oxford researchers have developed programmable microcapsules to deliver vaccines in stages, potentially eliminating the need for booster shots and increasing immunisation coverage in hard-to-reach communities.

title: Latest Rees Centre report calls for ethical and effective information use to improve children's lives
excerpt: A new report - 'Seen, Heard and Understood: Unlocking the Potential of Children’s Information Systems to Improve Outcomes' - released today by the Children’s Information Project and led by the Rees Centre at the University of Oxford, highlights a framework for the government to assess and improve the quality of children’s information use.

title: Honorary degrees awarded at Encaenia 2025
excerpt: Recipients of honorary degrees at Oxford University today included a Nobel laureate and a multiple Olympic, World and European champion, and represented the fields of sport, entertainment, broadcasting, science, politics, literature, journalism and academia.

title: How do vaccines reduce the risk of dementia?
excerpt: A new study by the University of Oxford, published in the journal npj Vaccines, shows that a vaccine against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is associated with a 29% reduction in dementia risk in the following 18 months. The findings suggest a novel explanation for how vaccines produce this effect.

title: New global index puts nature at the heart of human progress
excerpt: Researchers from the University of Oxford, alongside international partners including the United Nations Development Programme, have proposed an optimistic, practical approach to inspire stronger action on nature.

title: Oxford University researchers recognised in the 2025 Royal Society of Chemistry Prizes
excerpt: The Royal Society of Chemistry Prizes have celebrated excellence in the chemical sciences for more than 150 years. The 2025 Prizes recognise two individual Oxford academics who are helping to lay the scientific foundations for a cleaner, electrified energy future – from more efficient batteries to smarter solar technologies. A collaboration led by Oxford University also received a Horizon Prize for developing a cheaper and more sustainable method to manufacture important amine compounds.

title: Oxford University to lead new collaboration advancing zero carbon aviation through hydrogen
excerpt: Leading academics from Oxford University, Imperial College London, Loughborough University, and King's College London convened at the Oxford Thermofluids Institute on Thursday 5 June to mark the official launch of an ambitious programme focused on developing hydrogen-powered jet engines. The £9.5M project, backed by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC), aims to transform aviation by achieving net-zero emissions by 2050.

title: New Oxford research reveals Uber’s algorithmic pricing leaves drivers and passengers worse off
excerpt: A new study from researchers in the University of Oxford’s Department of Computer Science has found that Uber’s use of dynamic pricing has led to higher fares for passengers and lower earnings for drivers, whilst increasing Uber’s share of revenue.
